question: A passenger without a valid yellow fever certificate but who visited an infected area in the past six days must be treated how by the pilot-in-command?

choices.choice: Send a radio message two hours before the arrival about the state of the health of the passenger

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Incubation Periods for Quarantinable Diseases:
    • Yellow Fever: 6 days
    • Plague: 6 days
    • Cholera: 5 days
    • Smallpox: 14 days
    • Typhus: 14 days

  • Aircraft Health Reporting Requirement:

question: How long is a CPL holder’s medical validity period?

choices.choice: 1 year if age is less than 40 years

subject: Regulations
explanation:
For a CPL (Commercial Pilot License) holder:

  • If under 40 years of age, the medical certificate is valid for 1 year.
  • If 40 years or older, the medical certificate must be renewed more frequently, typically every 6 months (depending on the regulations of the licensing authority).

question: If an aircraft carries cargo for payment, what type of operation is it considered?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
A public transport aircraft carries passengers, cargo, or mail for hire or remuneration. It operates commercially, subject to strict aviation regulations for safety.

question: From India, when is an international flight permitted to depart?

choices.choice: from any major aerodrome in India

subject: Regulations
explanation:
• An aircraft entering India must land at a customs aerodrome for the first time in any journey, except in cases of unavoidable circumstances (e.g., accident, weather stress).
  • An aircraft departing India must also take off from a customs aerodrome, unless forced to land elsewhere due to similar unavoidable causes.

question: During aircraft refueling, at what distance must operations stop if another jet crosses nearby?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Fuelling operations shall cease when a turbo-jet aircraft manouvres so as to bring the rear jet outlets within 43 meters of the fuelling equipment or the aircraft.

question: Under what condition can a body of a person who died of cholera be brought into India?

choices.choice: Sealed in zinc and packed in a wooden box. Closed in a shell of zinc, joints sealed, shell enclosed in a teak wooden box which is enclosed in zinc lined box, filed with saw dust impregnated with carbolic powder.

subject: Regulations
explanation:
A corpse which has not been buried should be closed in a shell of zinc or other equally suitable metal with all joints so soldered as to seal them hermetically and prevent the escape of noxious gases or fluids. The shell should be enclosed in a stoutly built teak or other hard wood coffin and the coffin should be enclosed in a zinc or tin-lined wooden packing case filled with sawdust impregnated with carbolic powder.

question: Cabin crew requirements are determined according to which rule?

choices.choice: No. of passengers excluding crew members
No. of persons on board including crew members

subject: Regulations
explanation:
No aircraft registered in India shall be operated for public transport of passengers unless the following minimum number of cabin crew are on board:

  1. For an aeroplane with a seating capacity of 10 to 50 passengers: One cabin crew member is required.
  2. For a helicopter with a seating capacity of 20 to 50 passengers: One cabin crew member is required.
  3. For an aeroplane or helicopter with a seating capacity of more than 50 passengers: Two cabin crew members plus one additional cabin crew member for each unit (or part of a unit) of 50 passenger seats above 99.

question: An aircraft without registration markings can only be operated when?

choices.choice: If the sale deed is not yet completed
For purpose of test flight only, prior to purchase.
If specially permitted in writing by the central govt.

subject: Regulations
explanation: • Aircraft may not be flown unless they are registered and display nationality, registration marks, and the owner’s name and residence, per Rule 37 or the regulations of their registered country. Exceptions apply if the Central Government grants special written permission with specified conditions and limitations.

question: Human remains of a person who died from plague can be imported into India under what condition?

choices.choice: If enclosed in a shell of zinc.
If enclosed in a hermetically sealed shell of zinc after permission id obtained from proper authority

subject: Regulations
explanation:
No person shall bring into India any dead body or human remains of persons who may have died of yellow fever, plague, anthrax, ganders or such other diseases as may be notified by the Central Government for this purpose. If such body is properly cremated then ashes shall be placed in an urn or casket having an outer packing of suitable material may be brought to India. There are specification for bringing un- cremated remains.

question: While aircraft refueling is underway, no open flame may be within how many meters?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Smoking or the use of any appliance with an open flame or capable of producing sparks is prohibited within 30 meters of the aircraft or fueling equipment. This regulation is crucial to prevent the ignition of flammable vapors during refueling operations.

question: Each flight crew member must have their logbook verified by which authority?

choices.choice: At the end of each calendar month
At the end of every quarter
At an half yearly interval ending Jun and Dec

subject: Regulations
explanation:
1. Monthly Certification: Every flight crew member must certify the accuracy of their logbook entries at the end of each calendar month.
  2. Dual Instruction: The pilot-in-command must certify flight time entries during dual instruction.
  3. Quarterly Certification: Logbooks must be certified for correctness at the end of March, June, September, and December.
  4. Competent Authorities: Certification by designated authorities:
    • (a) Operations Manager, Deputy Operations Manager, or Chief Pilot for professional pilots.
    • (b) Chief Flying Instructor for members of a Flying Training Organization.
    • (c) Officers designated by the Director-General of Civil Aviation for all other personnel.
  5. Purpose: Ensures accuracy and compliance with flight time records.
  6. Responsibility: Both the flight crew and designated authorities share the responsibility for maintaining accurate logbooks.

question: Mathura Refinery is classified as what type of facility?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
These restricted areas are designated as no-fly zones in India, where aircraft operations are strictly prohibited for security, safety, or other regulatory reasons. Here’s a summary of each:

  1. Towers of Silence, Malabar Hills, Bombay:
    • Prohibited within a one-mile radius from this site.
  2. Baroda Aerodrome:
    • Restricted airspace from ground level to an unlimited upper level near the aerodrome.
  3. Rashtrapati Bhavan (President’s Residence):
    • Restricted airspace from ground level to an unlimited upper level around this area in New Delhi.
  4. Mathura Refineries:
    • No-fly zone within a 10-kilometer radius extending from ground level to an unlimited upper level.
  5. Bhubaneshwar:
    • Restricted from ground level to 50,000 feet over specified areas.
  6. Kalpakkam Nuclear Facility:
    • Prohibited within a 10-kilometer radius and extends from ground level to 10,000 feet above the facility.

  • Retention Period: Log books must be preserved for a minimum of 5 years after the date of the last entry.

question: A pilot may fly an aircraft not listed in their license only under which condition?

explanation:

question: If an IFR flight departs at 1032 UTC to Jaipur (sunset 1318 UTC, no night landing), what is the available flying time?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Daytime is defined as the period from half an hour before sunrise until half an hour after sunset. This means operations designated for “day” can technically extend slightly beyond the actual times of sunrise and sunset, which allows for better planning flexibility around twilight.

In the scenario of the aircraft bound for Jaipur:

  • Sunset at Jaipur is at 1318 UTC.
  • With the day period extending 30 minutes past sunset, daytime operations could continue until 1348 UTC.

This extended period explains why 3 hours and 06 minutes is considered the available flying time.

question: Dropping pamphlets from an aircraft requires prior approval from whom?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
Conditions under which dropping items like printed sheets or flower petals from an aircraft is permitted:

  1. Prior Permission: Written permission must be obtained from the District Magistrate or Commissioner of Police for each case.
  2. Aircraft Suitability: The aircraft must be appropriate and equipped for dropping these items.
  3. Minimum Safe Heights: The specified minimum safe heights in aviation regulations must be maintained.
  4. Safety Precautions: Necessary measures must be taken to prevent injury or property damage.

question: Prisoners may be carried on board with what authorization?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
• Requirement for Written Permit: No prisoner may be taken aboard or transported on an aircraft unless a written permit is issued. This permit must be authorized by:
    • The Director-General
    • A Deputy Director-General
    • The Director of Regulations and Information
    • Any other officer of the Civil Aviation Department authorized by the Central Government
  • Conditions of Permit: The permit may include specific conditions, as stipulated by the issuing authority.
  • Definition of “Prisoner”: The term “prisoner” refers to any person confined in a prison or anyone under arrest according to existing laws.

question: Operating crew members are prohibited from consuming alcohol within how many hours before duty?
subject: Regulations
explanation:
No person acting as or carried in aircraft for the purpose of acting as pilot, commander, navigator, engineer, cabin crew or other operating member of the crew thereof, shall have taken or used any alcoholic drink, sedative, narcotic or stimulant drug or preparation within twelve hours of the commencement of the flight.
